My Blog

Lab 2: Technology Choices for Headless CMS Implementation

Objective

The objective for this lab is to research five headless CMS systems—Strapi, Contentful, Sanity, Prismic, and Ghost—to determine which CMS works best for creating and maintaining a website. This Lab is written as a course requirement for INFT 3102 - Web Development (Frameworks).

What is a headless CMS?

A headless CMS is a content management system that provides a user-friendly frontend environment for creating and managing content. Headless CMS's separate the content's front end from its backend, making content accessible via an API so that it can be displayed on any device.

Strapi

Overview

Strapi is a headless CMS used to build websites, mobile apps, eCommerce platforms, and APIs. It is a free, open-source headless CMS that connects a website's front end and back end using an API.

Features

- Compatible with databases such as MongoDB, PostgreSQL, and others.

- Designed to scale automatically to handle heavy traffic.

Pros

1. Easy to use and versatile: Highly user-friendly and customizable with plugins, allowing for content creation without coding.

2. Open-Source and free: Strapi is freely available.

3. Scalable: Easily manages heavy traffic loads.

4. Reduces development time: Includes a user-friendly admin section for content management.

5. Accessible plugins: Offers plugins to enhance applications.

Cons

1. Limited TypeScript support: Requires external plugins for TypeScript

2. Constant updates: Frequent updates require careful management

3. Not entirely free: Paid versions include extra features.

4. Manual migration: Lacks automated content migration tools.

Conclusion

Strapi is a versatile and user-friendly headless CMS suitable for building APIs.

Contentful

Overview

A composable content platform for creating, managing, and distributing content across multiple platforms.

Features

- Includes starter templates for new projects.

- Offers powerful localization features.

-Webhooks notify users about events such as entry publication.

- Provides a CLI for managing spaces, content models, and more.

Pros

1. Extendable interface: Customizable and developer-friendly.

2. Structured content model: Tailored content types for specific projects.

3. Media management: Integrates with Bynder, Cloudinary, and Dropbox.

4. Migration tools: APIs and CLI tools automate content migrations.

Cons

1. API limitations: GraphQL API struggles with deep nested queries.

2. API rate limits: Affects high-traffic applications.

3. Data import challenges: Querying large datasets is difficult.

Conclusion

Ideal for managing content for e-commerce websites.

Ghost

Overview

An open-source CMS built on Node.js, primarily for blogs.

Features

- Supports custom redirects and content creation in Markdown.

- Includes a CLI for installation management.

Pros

1. SQLite and MySQL support.

2. Markdown support: Simplifies content creation.

3. Bloat-free: Focused tools lead to better performance

4. Built-in SEO tools.

Cons

1. Limited website functionality: Suited for blogging, not complex layouts

2. Limited multi-language support: Requires third-party integrations.

Conclusion

Best for blogging platforms.

Sanity

Overview

Provides tools for creating and managing websites or applications efficiently.

Features

1. Includes Sanity Studio for real-time collaboration.

2. API-driven with GraphQL support and webhooks.

3. Offers document version control and an image processor.

Pros

1. Fast loading experience.

2. User-friendly editing interface.

3. Seamless video support.

4. Scalable.

5. Supportive community.

Cons

1. Time-consuming development.

2. Manual input reliance.

3. High maintenance needs.

4. Limited built-in editing tools.

5. Costly for large data.

Conclusion

A flexible and customizable CMS for efficient content creation.

Prismic

Overview

API-driven CMS with an intuitive user interface for managing content.

Features

1. User-friendly text editor and image optimization.

2. Offers reusable components called "Slices".

Pros

1. User-friendly interface.

2. Content versioning and live previews.

3. Simple integration with third-party services.

4. Comprehensive documentation.

Cons

1. Costly: Paid plans needed for advanced features.

2. Limited customization support.

Conclusion

Efficient and reliable for hosting and managing websites.

Strapi Implementation

Why I chose Strapi for this project and the future

Strapi offers an excellent UI for content creation and management, extensive customization options, and thorough documentation. Setting up and running a website using Strapi was straightforward and enjoyable.

- [Ghost vs. Contentful: Choosing the Right Headless CMS for Your Team](https://buttercms.com/blog/ghost-vs-contentful/#core-features-of-contentful)

- [Sanity.io - The Most Popular Headless CMS Platform in 2023](https://staticmania.com/blog/sanity-cms-features-with-review)

- [Prismic Reviews with Details](https://staticmania.com/blog/prismic-cms-reviews)
